document.text: W. Lloyd Vaughan STRUGGLING WITH DOUBT Scripture Genesis 15-1815 My grace is nrfftefcat for yeu, far a y pewer Is made perfect hi weakness. 2 Cor. 129 Abraham was 75 years old and childless, and his wife Sarah was 65. when God called him to leave home and kin and go to the land that I will show you. With the call to this indefinite destination came the promise to make of Abraham a great nation. Abraham obeyed the call. Over the years, God renewed His promise to make of Abraham a great nation, but a child was not born. It is not surprising that as the years passed, and no child was born, Abraham should have wondered about the fulfillment of the promise. It is natural that doublts should have arisen. Abraham and Sarah grew impatient, and Sarah gave Abraham her servant. Hagar, after the custom of the time and region, to bear him a child. A son Ishmael was born, but Ishmael was not the son of Promise. The son of promise was to be the son of the wife, not of the slave woman. Finally, when Abraham was 100 years old, a son was born to him and Sarah, Isaac, the child of promise. They had waited 25 years from the first promise for its fulfillment. Abrahams experience over this long quarter-century of waiting and wondering and wandering shows very clearly that Gods ways are not mans ways, and man does not always understand Gods ways. Where

W. Lloyd Vaughan Publisher and Editor subject of his thinking. Every field of human endeavor requires study, if one is to make progress in it. In the area of Christian growth the individual has many resources available for increas ing the knowledge conducive to growth. Basic, of course, is the Bible, a treasure house of spiritual knowledge. If one has available no o th e r such resource, the Bible will prove adequate. By diligent and consistent study of the Bible and practice of its teachings, many have attained spiritual maturity. Even if one has available other resources for study, whether few or many, the Bible offers the greatest am ount of assistance for spiritual growth. Paul did not have the Scripture as we know them, but in his counsel to the Colossian Christians for grow ing spiritually, he advised them to let the word of Christ dwell in you richly . . . Christians today have the word of Christ, as it is recorded in the Bible. In addition to the Bible, many helpful works are available, books, articles in religious publications, seeking to inter pret for our clearer understand ing Gods revelation of Himself as it is recorded in the S criptures. They are so numerous that one cannot read them all, so one must be selective in his choices. Paul suggests another re source for Christian growth, singing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs with thankful ness in your hearts to God.
